conclusion: The basketball is dropped from rest at a height H above the ground, undergoes an inelastic collision with the ground, and rebounds to a maximum height h above the ground.
The magnitude of the air resistance experienced by the basketball during its motion is λ times the magnitude of the gravitational force acting on the basketball.

Diagram (a) shows a basketball being dropped from height H, colliding with the ground, and rebounding to height h. Diagram (b) shows a graph of force F versus height y, with a constant force F0 and a triangular variation.
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is the same for each collision with the ground.
The magnitude of the gravitational acceleration is g.
The basketball collides with the ground and rebounds to a maximum height h.
The magnitude of the gravitational force acting on the basketball during the collision is F0, and the magnitude of the air resistance experienced by the basketball during the collision is λF0.
The post-collision velocity of the basketball is the same for each collision with the ground.
The total kinetic energy of the basketball before the collision is (1/2)mv0^2, where m is the mass of the basketball and v0 is the initial velocity.
The total kinetic energy of the basketball after the collision is (1/2)mvf^2, where vf is the final velocity.
According to the conservation of energy, (1/2)mv0^2 = (1/2)mvf^2 + (1/2)mvf^2.
The final velocity vf is the same for each collision with the ground.
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is vf/v0 = 1.
Thus, the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is 1.
